Title.evidence: Anterolateral Versus Midline Skin Incision in Total Knee Arthroplasty: A Randomised Controlled Trial

Participants.evidence: Participants were eligible if they required TKA and were recruited from a single orthopedic center.

Intervention.evidence: assigned to either a midline or an anterolateral skin incision.

Objective.evidence: This study investigates whether an anterolateral skin incision reduces the area of skin hypesthesia and associated postoperative discomfort.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the area of skin hypesthesia, assessed using Semmes-Weinstein monofilament at 13 reference points at 6 weeks, 6 months, and 12 months postoperatively.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was conducted using a computer-generated sequence, with allocation concealment ensured.

Blinding.evidence: Outcome assessors were blinded to group assignments.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The anterolateral incision group demonstrated significantly smaller areas of hypesthesia compared to the midline group at all time points: 32 cm² vs. 76 cm² at 6 weeks, 14 cm² vs. 29 cm² at 6 months, and 7 cm² vs. 19 cm² at 1 year.

Harms.evidence: No adverse events were reported in either group.
